choices.text: Stop MDT give thalidomide
Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids
Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

questions.text: In a case where a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy (MDT) experiences a deterioration of existing lesions and nerve complications, what course of action would you consider taking next? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

 

The situation described, where pre-existing lesions worsen during multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, indicates a type 1 lepra reaction. In managing this condition, the recommended approach would be to continue MDT while initiating systemic steroid treatment.

 

  • Type 1 lepra reactions are marked by inflammation of existing skin lesions, leading to symptoms such as edema, redness, and pain. While ulcers are uncommon, the development of new lesions is exceptionally rare. Additionally, acute neuritis may occur, presenting with tenderness and impairment of both motor and sensory functions.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued. NSAIDs and oral steroids can be added to treat pain.
  • Thalidomide is considered the gold standard for treating severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum. However, it is not the Drug of Choice due to its high cost and potential for adverse drug reactions. In type II lepra reactions, patients may experience systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of new skin lesions.

 

Type I & II lepra reactions:

 

(ENL = Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Stop MDT give thalidomide

  • Thalidomide is an immunomodulatory drug that may be used in certain conditions, like leprosy and its complications.
  • However, stopping MDT is not recommended as it is crucial to continue the treatment of the primary disease. Thalidomide is not used as treatment for Type 1 lepra reaction in leprosy.

 

Option B. Continue MDT, start thalidomide –

While MDT should be continued, thalidomide is not typically used for nerve complications. It's used primarily for severe or recurrent erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) Type 2 Lepra reaction, which is an immune-mediated complication of leprosy.

 

Option C. Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids –

  • Stopping MDT is not advised as the antibiotics in MDT are essential for treating the bacterial infection causing the disease.
  • The MDT should be continued to prevent the development of drug resistance and to adequately treat the underlying infection.

 

Option D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids -

  • This is the correct management for a leprosy patient with nerve damage, which is likely due to an immune reaction called a leprosy reaction. Systemic corticosteroids are used to control the inflammation and prevent further nerve damage.
  • MDT should be continued to treat the underlying infection.
  • The reason for selecting option D is that systemic corticosteroids are effective in treating acute nerve inflammation and can prevent further damage while continuing MDT ensures that the infection is adequately treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of nerve complications in a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy for conditions like leprosy, the appropriate course of action is to continue the anti-microbial therapy and start systemic steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction causing nerve damage.

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.5, 28.12, 28.16

choices.text: Annular hymen

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image is suggestive of the septate hymen.
  • The hymen is the membranous vestige of the junction between the sino-vaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus, which perforates during fetal life to establish a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum.
  • Defective perforation of this structure may result in the following variants of hymen:
    • Imperforate hymen: Without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty)
    • Micro-perforate hymen: Tiny opening
    • Annular hymen: Oval central opening
    • Septate hymen: Two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (May have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon)
    • Naviculate hymen: Boat-like opening

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imperforate hymen: An imperforate hymen has no opening at all and often presents as cryptomenorrhea (accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen) at puberty.

 

Option B. Semilunar hymen: A semilunar hymen has a crescent-shaped opening and is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Annular hymen: An annular hymen has an oval central opening and does not match the septate appearance in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A septate hymen is characterized by two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue, which may lead to difficulties with intercourse or tampon use.

 

 

Ref: Page no 18, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: (FMGE JAN 2025)

 

  • pH: 7.50
  • PaCO₂: 48 mmHg
  • HCO₃: 33 mmol/L

 

What is the most likely acid-base disturbance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has metabolic alkalosis due to:

 

  • Elevated pH (> 7.45), indicating alkalemia.
  • Elevated HCO₃ (> 26 mEq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis.
  • Clinical history of vomiting, which leads to the loss of chloride (via gastric acid - Hcl), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.
  • Binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting suggests that the patient may suffer from bulimia nervosa, a psychiatric illness.
  • Compensatory increase in PaCO₂ (normal: 35-45 mmHg), as per expected compensation using the Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis:
    • Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16
    • In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2)
      So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. 
    • The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: Incorrect, as this would present with low pH (<7.4) and low HCO₃ (<24)

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect, as the patient’s pH is 7.5 (alkalotic) and in acidosis pH would generally be low (< 7.4)

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect, as this would present with low PaCO₂ (< 40) and high pH (>7.4)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic vomiting results in loss of chloride (in the vomitus), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic Alkalosis is usually characterized by elevated pH and HCO₃, with appropriate respiratory compensation (elevated PaCO₂ - due to hypoventilation).

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

 

  • This patient most likely has a bleeding peptic ulcer.
  •  Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) includes both gastric and duodenal ulcers.
  •  Aspirin, an NSAID, interferes with the protective role of prostaglandins on the gastric and duodenal mucosa, increasing the risk of peptic ulcer formation in the stomach and the duodenum.
  •  Common presentations of peptic ulcers include pain in the epigastrium, bleeding, and vomiting.
  • The history of aspirin use and alcohol consumption further supports the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.

 

Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)

 

  • Etiology: Helicobacter pylori infection and NSAID use.
  • Mechanism: NSAIDs like aspirin disrupt the protective mucosal layer, leading to ulcer formation.
  • Symptoms: Epigastric pain, hematemesis, melena.
  • Sequelae:
    • Bleeding (more common in duodenal ulcers)
    • Perforation leading to peritonitis
    • Stricture causing gastric outlet obstruction
    • Malignancy risk (only in gastric ulcers)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss:

 

  • Occurs following repeated vomiting or retching, often associated with an alcoholic binge.
  • Characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Presents with self-limiting hematemesis, not usually profuse.

 

Option B. Esophagitis:

 

  • Inflammation of the esophagus, often due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Results in chronic blood loss and commonly presents as anemia rather than sudden hematemesis.
  • Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia.

 

Option D. Esophageal varices:

 

  • Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus, often due to portal hypertension.
  • Common in patients with liver cirrhosis.
  • Presents with massive hematemesis, splenomegaly, and ascites, none of which are described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

questions.text: Type of tympanoplasty shown in image Below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type 4

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows Type 4 tympanoplasty (Wullstein classification) where:

 

  • The graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate
  • All ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes suprastructure) are absent
  • Only the footplate remains
  • Also called cavum minor tympanoplasty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1

 

  • Simple myringoplasty with intact ossicular chain
  • Graft placed on handle of malleus
  • All ossicles are present and functional

 

Option B. Type 2

 

  • Graft placed on incus or remnant of malleus
  • Partial ossicular defect
  • Malleus absent but incus present

 

Option C. Type 3

 

  • Also called columella tympanoplasty
  • Graft placed on stapes head
  • Malleus and incus absent but stapes suprastructure present

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Type 4 tympanoplasty as the procedure where the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate when all ossicles are absent except the footplate.

 

Tympanoplasty –

questions.text: An intra-operative image of a child undergoing inguinal hernia repair is shown, with a marked vein in the spermatic cord. What is the likely structure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testicular vein

 

During an open inguinal hernia repair, especially in the context of congenital hernias, the structures encountered within the spermatic cord are crucial for identification and preservation. The testicular vein is one of the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord, alongside the testicular artery and vas deferens. This vein is responsible for draining blood from the testes and is often seen during inguinal hernia repairs.

 

In the provided intraoperative image, the marked structure is consistent with the testicular vein due to its anatomical position and its association with the spermatic cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vein: The femoral vein lies posterior to the inguinal canal and is not encountered during an open inguinal hernia repair. It is located within the femoral triangle and is not related to the spermatic cord.

 

Option B. Obturator vein: The obturator vein is also located posterior to the inguinal canal, passing through the obturator foramen. It is not visible or involved in inguinal hernia repairs as it lies deep in the pelvis.

 

Option D. Inferior epigastric vein: The inferior epigastric vein is positioned anterior to the peritoneum and supplies the anterior abdominal wall. It does not travel within the spermatic cord and would not be seen during an open hernia repair involving the spermatic cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an open inguinal hernia repair, the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord are the testicular veins. Other veins such as the femoral, obturator, and inferior epigastric veins are located posterior to the inguinal canal and are not seen within the spermatic cord during such procedures.

questions.text: A child present with congenital defect in diaphragm which is located on posterior/postero-lateral aspect of chest. What is your diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bochdalek hernia

 

Bochdalek hernia is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia that occurs posterolaterally due to failure of fusion of pleuroperitoneal membrane during development. Based on a mnemonic “BPLLAR” used for diaphragmatic hernias:

 

  • B stands for Bochdalek hernia
  • P stands for posterior location
  • L stands for left side (more common) This type of hernia is more common posteriorly and on the left side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morgagni hernia: This occurs anteriorly and on the right side of the diaphragm. Using the same mnemonic BPLLAR:

 

 LAR 

 

  • Larry's hernia (Morgagni)
  • A stands for anterior location
  • R stands for right side

 

Option C. Hiatal hernia: This is a protrusion of stomach through the esophageal hiatus. It's not a posterolateral defect.

 

Option D. Eventration: This is an abnormal elevation of part of the diaphragm due to thinning of the muscle. It's not a true hernia and doesn't involve a posterolateral defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia, characterized by a posterior or posterolateral defect in the diaphragm, usually on the left side. It results from the failure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane to close and leads to pulmonary hypoplasia due to the herniation of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity.

choices.text: Abortion leading to death of mother
Preventing the child from being born alive

questions.text: IPC Section 314 deals with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abortion leading to death of mother

 

ABORTION IPC’S = 312-316 IPC’S, 317 & 318

 

312 – 316 → Criminal Abortion

 

312 – Criminal abortion with consent of mother (BNS section 88)

 

313 – Criminal abortion without the consent of mother (BNS section 89)

 

314 – Death of mother during criminal abortion (BNS section 90)

 

315 - Preventing a live birth or causing a live born to die after birth (BNS section 91)

 

316 – Causing death of quick born, by a heinous act which could have led to death of mother (ex: - hit on abdomen of mother) (BNS section 92)

 

317 - Abandoning of a child by parents when child age is <12 years (BNS section 93)

 

318 - Concealing the birth of a newborn by secret disposal of dead body (BNS section 94)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC Section 314 deals specifically with the death of the mother during a criminal abortion.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child complains of mild painful swelling over the scalp for 3 months as shown in the image below. He also has a pet dog at his home. What is the diagnosis of the given condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Kerion

 

  • The case of a young boy coming into contact with a zoophilic organism and displaying symptoms of a boggy inflammatory mass, accompanied by thick crusting and matting of hair, indicates a possible diagnosis of kerion.
  • Kerion is an intense inflammatory form of tinea capitis, caused by dermatophytes that have an affinity for animals (pet dog clue).

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms - T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount

 

Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum à Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton à Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furuncle:

  • Description: Also known as a boil, a furuncle is a deep folliculitis, an infection of the hair follicle.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Furuncles are typically more localized and painful and would not be described as "boggy." Also, they don’t have a direct association with having a pet dog.

 

Option B. Epidermoid cyst:

  • Description: These are benign cysts originating from the epidermis. They are filled with keratin and have a characteristic central punctum as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Epidermoid cysts are typically non-painful unless infected. They do not usually present as boggy swellings and are not related to having a pet.

 

Option D. Folliculitis:

  • Description: Folliculitis is the inflammation or infection of one or more hair follicles.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Folliculitis on the scalp would typically present as multiple small, itchy, and red pustules. It wouldn't create a boggy swelling as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kerion is a boggy, tender scalp swelling associated with hair loss and potentially linked to animal exposure, indicative of a fungal infection rather than a bacterial cause like furuncle or folliculitis, or a benign lesion such as an epidermoid cyst.

 

Reference: 

 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

The patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. The investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in many conditions like Sarcoidosis, Pneumoconiosis, TB, etc

 

But the other clinical features point towards sarcoidosis, a systemic inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs, but it commonly involves the lungs and lymph nodes. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding in sarcoidosis and is often the first clue in diagnosis. Additionally, sarcoidosis can present with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats.

 

The presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is another significant clue. While Guillain-Barre syndrome, Lyme disease, and sarcoidosis can cause bilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) type facial palsy, the combination of other symptoms and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy strongly favors sarcoidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis (TB) can present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy, including hilar lymphadenopathy. However, TB typically causes caseating granulomas and does not commonly present with bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can also present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy. However, it typically involves systemic B symptoms and other lymph node groups. Bilateral facial nerve palsy is not a common presentation of lymphoma.

 

Option D. Hypersensitive pneumonitis: Hypersensitive pneumonitis can present with respiratory symptoms and lymphadenopathy, but it is usually associated with exposure to inhaled organic antigens. It does not typically cause systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats and the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. Always consider sarcoidosis first in such clinical scenarios.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent a bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

 

  • Pain in the thigh (Meralgia Paraesthetica) is due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. This nerve entrapment often occurs during laparoscopic hernia repair, especially during the placement of mesh.
  •  The nerves commonly injured in laparoscopic repair are the genitofemoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves of the thigh.
  •  Patients with lateral cutaneous nerve injury present with acute neuropathic pain along the dermatomal distribution, resulting in meralgia paresthetica.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Treatment consists of rest, ice, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and possible local corticosteroid and anesthetic injection.
  • Drugs like gabapentin can be used to manage neuropathic pain.
  • In laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) repair, to reduce the chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve leads to sensory disturbances and pain over the skin of the genitalia and upper medial thigh. This nerve is most commonly injured in open repair of inguinal hernia, not laparoscopic repair.

 

Option B. Iliohypogastric nerve: The iliohypogastric nerve leads to pain in the inguinal and suprapubic regions. Injury to this nerve does not typically result in pain isolated to the thigh.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: Femoral nerve injury presents as lower limb numbness, weakness, tingling, paralysis, or pain along the nerve. However, femoral nerve injury is less likely to be caused by laparoscopic hernia repair and more often associated with other surgical procedures or traumatic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair.
  •  Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.

questions.text: This condition is treated by supplementation of which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicotinamide

 

The condition shown in the image is pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often referred to as the "three Ds" of pellagra. Pellagra is caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) or its precursor, tryptophan. Nicotinamide is the form of niacin that is typically used in supplementation to treat pellagra. Niacin supplementation helps replenish the body's stores of this essential nutrient and alleviates the symptoms associated with the deficiency. The hallmark sign in the image is the "casal necklace," a symmetrical, hyperpigmented rash around the neck, which is typical of pellagra.

 

Note –

 

If with this clinical scenario like Pellagra with an increase in xanthurenic acid in urine, it indicates that the niacin deficiency is likely due to a Vitamin B6 deficiency. In such cases, Vitamin B6 supplementation is recommended for the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency leads to symptoms such as night blindness and xerophthalmia, not the symptoms seen in pellagra.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant and its deficiency is associated with neurological problems, but it is not related to the symptoms of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums and petechiae, which is unrelated to the condition seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is treated with niacin or nicotinamide supplementation

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant female is advised to take folic acid supplements. Folic acid is given in pregnancy to prevent which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neural tube defects

 

Folic acid supplementation during pregnancy is crucial for the prevention of neural tube defects (NTDs), which are serious birth defects of the brain and spine, such as spina bifida and anencephaly. The neural tube forms early in pregnancy, often before a woman knows she is pregnant, which is why folic acid supplementation is recommended even before conception and during early pregnancy.

 

The recommended daily dose of folic acid for most pregnant women is 400 micrograms, but this dose may be increased to 4000 micrograms in women who are at higher risk for NTDs or are taking certain medications, such as anti-epileptic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: While folic acid can help prevent anemia due to folate deficiency, the primary reason for its supplementation during pregnancy is to prevent neural tube defects, not anemia.

 

Option C. Preeclampsia: Folic acid is not specifically used to prevent preeclampsia. Other interventions, such as calcium supplementation, are more relevant for preeclampsia prevention.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes: Folic acid does not play a role in the prevention of gestational diabetes. This condition is managed through diet, exercise, and, if necessary, medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation in pregnancy is essential to prevent neural tube defects, with the standard recommended dose being 400 micrograms per day, increased to 4000 micrograms for those at higher risk.

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery- External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uterine artery – Ovarian artery – Internal iliac artery

 

  • Stepwise devascularization in the management of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) involves:
    1. Ligation of the uterine arteries:
      • The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated at the lateral border between the upper and lower uterine segments.
    2. Ligation of the ovarian and uterine artery anastomoses:
      • Done just below the ovarian ligament.
      • Sometimes, temporary occlusion of the ovarian vessels may be achieved using rubber sleeved clamps.
    3. Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery:
      • This step reduces blood flow by decreasing the pulse pressure by 85%.
      • Ligation can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery: The external iliac artery is not typically involved in the stepwise devascularization for managing atonic PPH.

 

Option C. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery: Ligation of the vaginal artery is not part of the typical sequence in managing atonic PPH.

 

Option D. Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery: The pudendal artery and vaginal artery are not typically targeted in the stepwise devascularization for atonic PPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stepwise devascularization approach for managing atonic postpartum hemorrhage includes ligation of the uterine arteries, ovarian arteries, and anterior division of the internal iliac arteries in that specific order.

 

Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the upper GI endoscopy image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal varices

 

The image shows dilated column of veins in the veins suggestive of esophageal varices. They are seen in portal hypertension and present with hematemesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barrett’s esophagus: Characterised by salmon coloured tongue like patches at GE junction

 

 

Option C. Gastric erosions: Lesions seen in stomach due to H. Pylori.

 

 

 

Option D. Esophageal candida: Appear as milky/curdy white patches.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated column of veins in esophagus represent varices.

questions.text: Which influenza virus was responsible for the 2009 pandemic? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) H1N1

 

The 2009 influenza pandemic, commonly referred to as the "swine flu" pandemic, was caused by the H1N1 influenza A virus. This virus emerged in Mexico and quickly spread worldwide, causing widespread illness and leading to a global pandemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H5N1: Known as the "bird flu" virus.

 

  • Year: First identified in 1997 in Hong Kong.
  • Impact: Primarily affects birds but can infect humans, causing severe respiratory illness.

 

Option C. H5N7: This subtype of influenza is not known to have caused any major pandemics or widespread outbreaks in humans.

 

Option D. H3N2: This subtype of influenza A virus is known to cause seasonal flu epidemics but was not responsible for the 2009 pandemic.

 

  • Year: H3N2 was involved in the 1968 influenza pandemic, known as the "Hong Kong flu."

 

Educational Objective:

 

Influenza Pandemics

 

SWINE FLU, H1N1 → 2009, Mexico

BIRD FLU, H7N9 → 2013, China

BIRD FLU, H5N1 → 1997, Hong Kong

BIRD FLU, H10N3 → 2021, China

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) presents with an acute attack of migraine. Which of the following medications should not be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

 

Sumatriptan is a medication used to treat acute migraine attacks and works as a selective serotonin receptor agonist (5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist). However, it is contraindicated in patients with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) or other significant cardiovascular diseases, including previous myocardial infarction (MI). This is because sumatriptan can cause vasoconstriction, which can exacerbate these conditions, leading to serious cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ibuprofen:  A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can be used to treat migraine pain. It does not have the same cardiovascular risks as triptans and can be safely used in patients with a history of MI, although caution is advised in hypertensive patients.

 

Option C. Propranolol:  A beta-blocker often used for migraine prophylaxis. It is actually beneficial for patients with a history of MI as it reduces the risk of further cardiac events by lowering heart rate and blood pressure.

 

Option D. Verapamil: A calcium channel blocker that is sometimes used for migraine prevention. It is generally safe for use in patients with a history of MI and can help manage hypertension as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sumatriptan, a vasoconstrictor, should not be given to patients with a history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction due to the risk of triggering serious cardiovascular events.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. Mark the correct biochemical changes which will be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urate and lactate levels

 

This patient with chronic alcoholism and gouty arthritis will most likely have elevated levels of lactate and urate.

 

The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by alcohol dehydrogenase is accompanied by the reduction of NAD+ to NADH. This results in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio (Hence ruled out Option A).

 

 

Due to this, the following metabolic reactions which require NAD+ are inhibited:

  1. Glycolysis
  2. Citric acid cycle (ketogenesis favoured)
  3. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  4. Fatty acid oxidation

 

This decreased fatty acid oxidation leads to increased esterification and production of triacylglycerol, which causes fatty liver.

In addition to this, there is an increase in two reactions:

  • Pyruvate to lactate
  • Oxaloacetate to malate

 

Increased lactate leads to hyper-lactic-acidemia, which leads to increased renal reabsorption of urate and decreased excretion of uric acid. This results in aggravation of gout.

 

Alcoholics are deficient in thiamine which inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase and these all leads to lactic acidosis.

 

A decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis, leads to a decrease in blood glucose levels, causing symptoms of agitation, impaired judgement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio: This is incorrect as the NADH/NAD+ ratio is actually increased due to the metabolism of ethanol.

 

Option B: Increased urea and urate levels are not specifically associated with alcoholism and gouty arthritis. But urate levels may be increased due to gout, urea levels are not directly related to the condition.

 

Option D: Increased levels of alkaline phosphatase can be seen in alcohol-induced hepatitis due to intrahepatic cholestasis but is not directly related to gouty arthritis in a chronic alcoholic patient. Therefore, this option is less relevant compared to increased rate and lactate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

The histopathology shows trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal lumen

 

 

  • Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.
  • ﻿﻿Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the faeco-oral route.
  • ﻿﻿It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.
  • ﻿﻿The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.
  • ﻿﻿Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which is typically associated with bloody diarrhea or dysentery and liver abscesses, not the watery diarrhea commonly seen with Giardia.

 

Option C. Microsporidia: A group of obligate intracellular parasites, known to cause diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, but they do not produce the trophozoites seen in Giardia infections.

 

Option D. Cryptosporidia: Another protozoan that can cause watery diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients, but is identified by different morphological features on histology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Giardia lamblia is a significant cause of diarrheal disease, especially in settings where water or food might be contaminated. Its unique trophozoites are diagnosable through histopathology, emphasizing the need for awareness of water and food hygiene to prevent its transmission. Treatment typically involves specific anti-protozoal medications, and addressing it effectively is crucial in immunocompromised patients to prevent prolonged symptoms and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary lymphoid organ? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymus

 

Primary lymphoid organs are those where lymphocytes, such as T cells and B cells, develop and mature. The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ responsible for the maturation of T cells. It provides an environment for precursor cells to develop into mature T lymphocytes, which are essential for adaptive immunity. The thymus plays a critical role in establishing central tolerance, ensuring that T cells that react against self-antigens are eliminated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spleen: The spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ where immune responses are initiated. It filters the blood and houses immune cells but is not involved in the maturation of lymphocytes.

 

Option B. Lymph node: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. They filter lymphatic fluid and serve as sites where immune responses are initiated but do not participate in the initial development or maturation of lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Tonsils: Tonsils are also considered secondary lymphoid organs. They play a role in the immune response to pathogens entering through the mouth or nose but are not involved in lymphocyte maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ where T cells mature, playing a crucial role in the development of the immune system.

 

Spleen, lymph node and tonsils are considered as secondary lymphoid organs

 

Bone marrow has been considered as an example of both a primary as well as a secondary lymphoid organ.

questions.text: In methanol poisoning, which of these is increased in the blood? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Formic acid and lactic acid


Methanol poisoning occurs when methanol is metabolized in the body. Methanol is first converted to formaldehyde, which is then further metabolized to formic acid. Formic acid is toxic and interferes with cellular respiration, inhibiting the normal production of ATP. This interference pushes the body towards anaerobic metabolism, leading to the accumulation of lactic acid in the blood. Therefore, in methanol poisoning, both formic acid and lactic acid levels are elevated due to disrupted cellular respiration and subsequent anaerobic metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formic acid and glycolic acid: Glycolic acid is primarily associated with ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. In methanol poisoning, formic acid is the primary metabolite responsible for toxicity.

 

Option B. Oxalic and formic acid: Oxalic acid is a major toxic metabolite of ethylene glycol, not methanol. In methanol poisoning, formic acid is the main toxic substance, and oxalic acid does not play a role.

 

Option C. Glycolic and lactic acid: Glycolic acid is related to ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. While lactic acid can be elevated due to anaerobic metabolism, glycolic acid is not a product of methanol metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:


In methanol poisoning, formic acid and lactic acid levels increase due to disrupted cellular respiration and anaerobic metabolism.

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Normal pressure hydrocephalus

 

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is characterized by the triad of dementia, gait disturbance (typically apraxia or magnetic gait), and urinary incontinence. This condition often involves enlargement of the cerebral ventricles due to cerebrospinal fluid accumulation, which can exert pressure on surrounding brain structures, particularly affecting the frontal lobes responsible for cognitive and urinary control. The clinical presentation aligns well with the symptoms described in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontotemporal dementia: This condition often presents with prominent personality changes and language difficulties rather than the classic triad seen in NPH. Falls are less commonly associated with this form of dementia in its early stages.

 

Option C. Parkinson disease: Typically presents with motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. While dementia can occur in later stages, it is not typically accompanied by urinary incontinence and would not explain the early presence of falls as the primary symptom.

 

Option D. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: Known for rapid progression of neurological symptoms including dementia, myoclonus (sudden muscle spasms), and significant motor dysfunction. It progresses much faster than what is typically seen in NPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NPH is characterized by Dementia, Apraxia/Magnetic gait with urinary incontinence due to frontal lobe dysfunction

 

Reference - Harrison/Dementia/Chap 434

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shock

 

Apoplexy refers to acute neurologic impairment due to a vascular compromise, usually hemorrhage, resulting in headache, visual disturbance and hormonal dysfunction due to infarction of pituitary gland.

 

Loss of glucocorticoids results in shock.

 

MRI is used to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Management:

 

  • If shock is present: IV glucocorticoids + IV fluids to maintain hemodynamic stability
  • If worsening neurologic symptoms (VA, GCS): Surgical decompression

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertension: Typically, hypertension is not a direct consequence of pituitary apoplexy. Instead, hypotension and shock are more common due to adrenal insufficiency.

 

Option C. Unconsciousness: While not the most direct symptom, unconsciousness can occur if the apoplexy leads to significant increase in intracranial pressure or severe complications, but it's not as characteristic as shock.

 

Option D. Fatigue: Although patients may experience fatigue due to hormonal imbalances, it's not a primary or immediate concern in the acute setting of pituitary apoplexy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shock is a critical and life-threatening manifestation of pituitary apoplexy that arises from acute adrenal insufficiency. Immediate recognition and treatment with IV glucocorticoids and fluids are essential to stabilize the patient and prevent further complications. This condition is diagnosed via imaging, typically an MRI, and may require surgical intervention depending on the severity and the presence of neurological symptoms.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Pituitary tumor syndromes/Page no 2897

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

 

Explanation:

 

  • Misoprostol and Mifepristone:
    • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
    • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
    • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
    • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.

 

Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.

 

 

Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules

questions.text: Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is seen in? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Psoriasis

 

Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is most commonly seen in psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin condition.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It is an inflammatory non-infectious disease characterized by an imbalance in T-cell subsets. There is an elevated number of activated Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells, while Th2 cells are deficient.

 

Cytokines in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Genetic predisposition: n Type 1 plaque psoriasis and guttate psoriasis with HLA C:06:02 association.
  • Around 5-30% of individuals with cutaneous psoriasis also develop psoriatic arthritis (PsA), a condition affecting the joints.
  • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus:

  • Lichen planus can affect the nails and produce nail changes, but the common manifestations are nail thinning, ridging, or even complete loss of the nail.
  • Pterygium formation, where there's scarring of the cuticle area leading to the nail's progressive loss, can also be seen.
  • While lichen planus can cause nail pitting, it's typically not associated with subungual hyperkeratosis, a feature more consistent with psoriasis.

 

Option C. Vitiligo:

  • Vitiligo is a disorder where there's a loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) leading to white patches on the skin.
  • It doesn't typically produce pitting of nails.

 

Option D: Alopecia areata:

Geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of the nails is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriasis is the condition most commonly associated with irregular nail pitting and subungual hyperkeratosis among the options provided.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 4.9, 35.4-35.34, 37.12, 41.1, 41.21 89.28-33

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What can be done to prevent future thrombotic events? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Oral warfarin

 

The patient is diagnosed with mitral stenosis and has an irregularly irregular pulse, indicating atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is a common complication in patients with mitral stenosis and significantly increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

 

Long-term anticoagulation therapy is essential in such patients to prevent these events. The presence of mitral stenosis, particularly moderate to severe, mandates the use of oral anticoagulants. Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant in this scenario because it is the only approved medication for patients with mitral stenosis and those with mechanical prosthetic heart valves.

 

Other anticoagulants, such as Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs), are not recommended in patients with valvular atrial fibrillation (AF associated with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves).

 

Additional Information –

 

CHA2DS2-VASc score to guide anticoagulation therapy in patients without mitral stenosis or a prosthetic valve.

 

  • C - Congestive heart failure: 1 point
  • H - Hypertension: 1 point
  • A - Age 65 to 74: 1 point, Age 75 and above: 2 points
  • D - Diabetes Mellitus: 1 point
  • S2 - Prior stroke or TIA: 2 points
  • Sex category (Female): 1 point
  • Vascular diseases (such as coronary artery disease or peripheral artery disease): 1 point

 

Scoring and Treatment Recommendations

 

  • Total Points: Ranges from 0 to 9.
  • Score of 2 or more: Strongly indicates the need for long-term anticoagulation (DOAC > warfarin).

 

Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) such as Dabigatran, Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, or Edoxaban are preferred unless the patient has conditions like mitral stenosis or mechanical prosthetic valves, in which case Warfarin might be more appropriate.

 

  • Score less than 2: Anticoagulation may be considered but is less mandatory.

 

This scoring system is crucial for making informed decisions about anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, tailoring treatment based on individual risk profiles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a DOAC that is not recommended for patients with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves. It is suitable for non-valvular atrial fibrillation but not for valvular AF.

 

Option B. Aspirin 150mg: Aspirin is not sufficient as an anticoagulant in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially those with mitral stenosis. It does not provide the necessary anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic events in such high-risk patients.

 

Option D. Aspirin + Clopidogrel: This combination is also inadequate for anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation, particularly in patients with mitral stenosis. While it can prevent platelet aggregation, it does not provide the anticoagulation required to prevent thrombus formation in atrial fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with atrial fibrillation associated with mitral stenosis, oral warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant to prevent thromboembolic events.

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Viper

 

Since, the patient is bleeding profusely from the wound site, the most likely cause is a bite of viper snake, a vasculotoxic snake.

 

  • Cobra is a neurotoxic snake, and will cause paralysis, instead of bleeding
  • Russell’s Viper is mainly vasculotoxic, but also neurotoxic to some extent
  • Krait and Sea Snake have minimal local symptoms
  • Russell’s viper is mainly vasculotoxic, but also has some neurotoxic features
  • Most common poisonous snake in India are (Big Four): 
    • Krait (Most Common)
    • Cobra,
    • Russell’s Viper
    • Saw Scaled Viper
  • Anti snake venom (ASV) in India is effective against all the above 4 snakes (polyvalent). It does not have antiserum against pit viper, but still partially effective due to cross antibodies
  • In Neurotoxic snakes, neostigmine should also be given in addition to ASV

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cobra:

 

  • Type: Neurotoxic snake.
  • Symptoms: Causes paralysis rather than bleeding.
  • Mechanism: Cobra venom affects the nervous system, leading to paralysis.

 

Option C. Wasp Bite:

 

Local: there is pain, itching, redness and slight Swelling at the site of the sting. 

 

Systemic: Systemic reactions occur due to multiple stinging with signs of GIT disturbance (nausea, vomiting and diarrhea), sweating, bronchospasm, hypotension, shock and unconsciousness.

 

Immediate anaphylactic reactions may be seen in some cases.

 

Option D. Scorpion Bite:

 

Action: The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator, resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It has also some direct effect on the myocardium.

 

Signs and Symptoms Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles develop within hours.

 

Local: Little swelling, but prominent radiating pain, reddening, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (tap test).

 

Systemic: Nausea, vomiting, restlessness, fever, headache, blurred vision, abnormal eye movement, profuse sweating and salivation, lacrimation, rhinorrhoea, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, jerking and shaking, slow pulse, cyanosis, convulsions, coma and respiratory depression, and death

 

Treatment of Scorpion bite: Anti scorpion venom, Prazosin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viper bites are characterized by profuse bleeding, pain, redness, and blister formation due to their vasculotoxic venom.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the detection of monkeypox? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PCR

 

The standard technique for the detection of monkeypox is Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR). PCR is a molecular technique used to amplify and detect the DNA of the orthopoxvirus, which includes the monkeypox virus. This method is highly sensitive and specific, making it the preferred choice for diagnosing monkeypox. PCR can detect the presence of orthopoxvirus DNA in various clinical specimens, providing a definitive diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: While an IgM ELISA test can detect antibodies against monkeypox and can become positive about 5 to 8 days after infection, it is not the primary method for initial detection of the virus itself.

 

Option C. Western blot: This technique is used to detect specific proteins in a sample and is not typically used for the detection of viral DNA in the diagnosis of monkeypox.

 

Option D. Hemagglutination: This assay is used to detect the ability of viruses to agglutinate red blood cells. It is not commonly used for the diagnosis of monkeypox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective and standard method for the detection of monkeypox is PCR, which detects the DNA of the orthopoxvirus in clinical specimens.

questions.text: Following delivery at a PHC, a patient was referred with the following image. On examination, there is a tear extending to the rectum. Identify the type of tear. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4th degree


Perineal tears are classified based on the extent of tissue damage during childbirth:

 

  1. 1st degree: Involves only the vaginal mucosa or skin of the perineum without involving deeper tissues.
  2. 2nd degree: Extends deeper, involving the perineal muscles but does not reach the anal sphincters; similar to an episiotomy.
  3. 3rd degree: Involves the anal sphincter complex with further sub-classifications:
    • 3a: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3b: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3c: Both the external and internal anal sphincters are involved.
  4. 4th degree: Extends through the rectal mucosa, completely disrupting the sphincters and the rectal lining.

 

Since the tear extends to the rectum, this is classified as a 4th degree tear, the most severe type, involving the entire perineum, anal sphincters, and rectal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:


A 4th degree tear involves disruption of the anal sphincters and rectal mucosa, making it the most severe form of perineal tear during childbirth.

questions.text: Within the framework of Sustainable Development Goal 3, the objective of target 3.1 is to achieve a reduction in the Maternal Mortality Ratio to what specific level (per 1 lakh live birts) by the year 2030? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) <70

 

In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to <70 per 1 lakh live births.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SDGs – Targets & Indicators

 

3.1 - By 2030, MMR < 70

3.2 - By 2030, NNMR 12 & U5MR 25

3.3 - By 2030, end epidemics of AIDS, TB, Malaria and NTDs and combat Hepatitis, Water-borne diseases and other CDS.

3.4 - By 2030, reduce by 1/3 premature mortality from NCDs.

3.5 - Strengthen the prevention & treatment of substance abuse.

3.6 - By 2020, halve the global deaths and injuries form RTA.

3.7 - By 2030, universal access to Sexual & Rep – health care services.

3.8 - Achieve Universal health coverage.

3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lecithin

 

Specifically phosphatidylcholine, is a major component of pulmonary surfactant. Surfactant plays a crucial role in reducing surface tension in the alveoli of the lungs, preventing their collapse. A deficiency in lecithin can contribute to respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cephalin: Cephalin is a type of phospholipid, and while it is present in cell membranes, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not directly associated with respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option B. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is another type of phospholipid found in cell membranes. The deficiency to recycle this lipid due to defective lysosomal enzyme sphingomyelinase cause sphingolipidoses also known as Niemann Pick disease.

 

Option D. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is a phospholipid found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and bacterial membranes. The disease associated with cardiolipins are anti-phospholipid syndrome and Barth syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS is a common condition in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production, particularly the deficiency of lecithin. The educational objective is to understand the etiology of RDS and its association with surfactant components, specifically lecithin. This knowledge is crucial for healthcare professionals involved in the care of neonates, as RDS can have serious respiratory consequences in premature infants and requires appropriate management and support.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine evaluation. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 24 weeks. Ultrasonography revealed decreased amniotic fluid. Which of the following conditions would have led to this presentation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis: Absence of both kidneys, leading to a lack of urine production, which is a major component of amniotic fluid.
    • Bilateral dysplastic kidneys: Kidneys that do not function properly, also leading to reduced urine output.
    • Bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease: This genetic disorder causes the kidneys to develop cysts, impairing their function.
    • Complex genito-urinary anomalies: Conditions like persistent cloaca and sirenomelia can affect kidney and urinary tract development, leading to oligohydramnios.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal Fistula: Tracheoesophageal fistula typically leads to polyhydramnios due to an obstruction to swallowing, resulting in an accumulation of amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Cardiac Abnormalities: Cardiac abnormalities usually lead to cardiac failure, which can result in fetal hydrops and polyhydramnios due to fluid accumulation in various fetal compartments.

 

Option D. Ureteral Stricture: Ureteral stricture will not lead to oligohydramnios unless there is bilateral involvement, which would be less common than the systemic impact of renal agenesis or other significant renal anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be caused by renal anomalies, with bilateral renal agenesis being a primary condition leading to reduced amniotic fluid levels.

 

Ref: Page no 670, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: In Presence of ADH, Maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid will be in which of the following site of nephron? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medullary CD

 

Explanation: 

 

ADH increases water permeability in the collecting ducts by inserting aquaporin channels. When ADH is present, as we move from the cortex towards the deep medulla, osmolarity keeps increasing. Though ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum change in osmolarity occurs in the medullary region due to the countercurrent multiplication system maintaining high osmolarity in the medullary interstitium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT: Incorrect because PCT mainly handles obligatory water reabsorption (60-70%) through osmosis, not regulated by ADH.

 

Option B. Cortical CD: Incorrect because although ADH acts here, the osmotic gradient in the cortex is much lower than in the medulla.

 

Option C. DCT: Incorrect because DCT has minimal water reabsorption (1-3%) without ADH and is not a major site for ADH action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid is achieved in the medullary collecting duct due to the high osmotic gradient maintained by the countercurrent multiplication system in the medulla.

questions.text: A 1-week-old child was presented with early cataract. He also has refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis. This can be caused due to the deficiency of which enzyme? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase

 

The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of classic galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). This enzyme deficiency leads to an accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate, which causes toxicity, especially in the liver, kidney, and lens of the eye.

 

The symptoms presented in the question are early cataract, refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis—are typical of galactosemia. The cataract seen in these patients is often described as an "," which is due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens, a metabolite of galactose.

 

 

Galactosemia can be of three types:

 

  • Type 1: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency (most common and severe form).
  • Type 2: Galactokinase deficiency.
  • Type 3: UDP-galactose-4-epimerase deficiency.

 

Among these, Type 1 galactosemia (GALT deficiency) is responsible for the symptoms described and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is not associated with galactose metabolism or the symptoms described, making this an incorrect choice.

 

Option C. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase converts galactose to galactitol in the lens, contributing to cataract formation in patients with galactosemia. However, the enzyme's deficiency is not the primary cause of the described condition; instead, its action exacerbates the effects of galactosemia.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the phosphorylation of glucose, not galactose. It plays no direct role in the pathogenesis of galactosemia or the symptoms mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase and presents with early cataracts, feeding difficulties, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis in newborns.

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dL) and LDL 220 mg/dL were found to be raised. What is the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LDL receptors defect

 

The patient's symptoms of multiple tendon xanthomas, elevated serum cholesterol, and high LDL levels indicate Type II hyperlipoproteinemia, commonly known as familial hypercholesterolemia. This condition is primarily caused by a defect in LDL receptors, leading to impaired clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. The resulting elevated LDL levels promote cholesterol deposition in tendons, forming xanthomas. Treatment typically focuses on reducing LDL cholesterol levels through diet, medication, or in severe cases, LDL apheresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency: This defect leads to Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by high levels of chylomicrons and triglycerides, but not elevated LDL or cholesterol. Symptoms typically include pancreatitis and eruptive xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas.

 

Option C. Apo E defect: Apo E defect leads to Type III hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as dysbetalipoproteinemia. This condition is associated with elevated remnants of chylomicrons and VLDL, resulting in palmar xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas, and does not specifically cause the high LDL levels seen in this patient.

 

Option D. LCAT deficiency: LCAT deficiency affects HDL cholesterol conversion to cholesterol esters and does not directly affect LDL levels. It is associated with conditions such as Norum disease or fish eye disease, presenting with corneal opacity and hemolytic anemia rather than tendon xanthomas or elevated LDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDL receptor defects cause familial hypercholesterolemia, characterized by elevated LDL, cholesterol levels, and tendon xanthomas.

choices.text: Reduce the swelling and do the observation
Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about a patient who presented in the OPD with a swelling as shown in the image? The swelling is reducible. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

 

The image shows a reducible swelling on the patient's back, which strongly suggests a hernia. Hernias are defined as protrusions of an organ or tissue through an abnormal opening. When a hernia is reducible, it means that the protruded organ or tissue can be pushed back into its original place.

 

The standard treatment for a reducible hernia is surgical repair. This often involves reducing the hernia and reinforcing the weakened area with a mesh to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly important to avoid complications such as strangulation or incarceration of the herniated contents, which can become medical emergencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and drainage: This procedure is typically used for abscesses or other collections of pus, not for hernias. Hernias do not require drainage as there is no infection involved.

 

Option B. Reduce the swelling and do the observation: While reducing the swelling might temporarily alleviate symptoms, observation alone is not a definitive treatment for a hernia. Without surgical repair, the hernia is likely to recur and may lead to complications.

 

Option D. Observation alone: This option is not advisable for hernias as it does not address the underlying defect in the abdominal wall or the risk of potential complications. Hernias generally require surgical intervention to prevent recurrence and complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For reducible hernias, the appropriate treatment is surgical repair with mesh reinforcement to prevent recurrence and avoid complications. Observation alone is not sufficient, and procedures such as incision and drainage are not applicable.

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV 60fL, and RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HbA2 levels

 

Question is testing applied knowledge. Mentzer’s index needs to be calculated 

 

A peripheral blood smear with microcytic hypochromic cells and a Mentzer index of less than 13 indicates thalassemia. As a result, HbA2 levels (which are elevated in thalassemia) must be tested next.

 

The Mentzer index, also known as the MCV/RBC count, can be used to distinguish thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia (IDA). In both IDA and thalassemia, MCV (mean corpuscular volume) and MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) are low. RBC count may be normal in thalassemia but decreased in IDA. A lower RBC count in IDA indicates a smaller denominator, resulting in a higher MCV/RBC ratio.

 

Mentzer index is

 

  • More than 13 in iron-deficiency anemia
  • Less than 13 in thalassemia

 

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival.

 

Clinical features in thalassemia include anemia, jaundice, skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habits, growth impairment, and hepatosplenomegaly. Due to frequent blood transfusions, iron overload is also seen.

 

Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum ferritin levels: Relevant for diagnosing iron deficiency anemia but less specific for thalassemia.

 

Option C. Serum folate levels: Relevant for diagnosing macrocytic anemia due to folate deficiency, not typically useful for microcytic anemia.

 

Option D. Serum homocysteine levels: Elevated in cases of vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, related to macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

For a patient presenting with microcytic hypochromic anemia and an RBC count suggesting thalassemia (Mentzer index < 13), the next best investigation is to measure HbA2 levels to confirm the diagnosis of beta-thalassemia.

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise skipped a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Alcohol inhibits which of the following biochemical processes, potentially leading to hypoglycemia: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gluconeogenesis

 

The question describes a clinical scenario where alcohol consumption after exercise and skipping meals leads to hypoglycemia. Alcohol inhibits gluconeogenesis through several mechanisms:

 

  1. Alcohol metabolism produces excess NADH through: 
    • Conversion of alcohol to acetaldehyde (ADH reaction)
    • Conversion of acetaldehyde to acetate (ALDH reaction)
  2. Excess NADH causes: 
    • Conversion of pyruvate to lactate
    • Conversion of oxaloacetate to malate
  3. This leads to depletion of pyruvate and oxaloacetate, which are essential substrates for gluconeogenesis
  4. Since the patient has exercised and skipped meals, glycogen stores are already depleted, making gluconeogenesis crucial for maintaining blood glucose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycogenolysis - Incorrect

 

  • Alcohol does not directly inhibit glycogenolysis
  • However, after strenuous exercise and skipping meals, glycogen stores would already be depleted

 

Option C. Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) Shunt - Incorrect

 

  • Alcohol does not directly affect the HMP shunt
  • HMP shunt is primarily involved in NADPH production and not glucose homeostasis

 

Option D. Ketone Body Formation - Incorrect

 

  • Alcohol actually promotes ketone body formation due to increased Acetyl-CoA from alcohol metabolism
  • This leads to alcoholic ketosis rather than inhibition

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol consumption inhibits gluconeogenesis by creating a high NADH/NAD+ ratio, which depletes gluconeogenic substrates (pyruvate and oxaloacetate), potentially leading to hypoglycemia, especially when glycogen stores are depleted.

questions.text: During delivery of a 30y G2P1L1 with previous LSCS, the head was delivered but the shoulders got stuck. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shoulder dystocia

 

Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency where, after the delivery of the fetal head, the shoulders fail to deliver within a typical interval. The definition of shoulder dystocia includes a delivery interval between the head and the shoulders exceeding one minute or requiring specific maneuvers to release the shoulders. This condition occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts behind the maternal pubic symphysis or, less commonly, the posterior shoulder impacts the sacral promontory.

 

In this scenario, the head was delivered, but the shoulders got stuck, fitting the clinical definition of shoulder dystocia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPD (Cephalopelvic Disproportion): This is incorrect as CPD refers to a mismatch between the size of the fetal head and the maternal pelvis, preventing the fetal head from entering or passing through the birth canal. It does not specifically describe the situation where the shoulders get stuck after the head is delivered.

 

Option C. Occipito posterior: This option is incorrect because it refers to the fetal head being positioned posteriorly in the pelvis, which can cause prolonged labor but does not directly result in shoulder dystocia. In occipito posterior positions, the delivery complication is typically a "face to pubis" delivery, not shoulder entrapment.

 

Option D. Transverse lie: This is incorrect as it describes a fetal position where the fetus lies horizontally in the uterus, which leads to complications like neglected shoulder with hand prolapse if the membranes rupture. The presentation is the shoulder, not the head, which means it does not fit the scenario where the head is delivered but the shoulders are stuck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shoulder dystocia is diagnosed when the shoulders fail to deliver within a minute after the head or require specific maneuvers for delivery.

questions.text: How does this graft get nutrition on day 3? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Inosculation

 

In the process of skin graft healing, the nutrition of the graft changes over time:

 

  1. Imbibition (Days 1-2): During the first two days after the graft is placed, it receives nutrition through plasmatic imbibition. This process involves the absorption of nutrients from the wound bed by diffusion into the graft.
  2. Inosculation (Days 3-5): By the third day, inosculation occurs, which involves the connection of blood vessels from the recipient bed to the blood vessels within the graft. This is a crucial step where initial vascular connections start to form between the graft and the recipient site, providing direct blood flow to the graft.
  3. Neovascularisation (After Day 5): After the fifth day, new blood vessels begin to grow into the graft from the recipient bed, a process known as neovascularization. This ensures that the graft has a stable blood supply, enhancing its long-term survival.
  4. Vascular Anastomosis: This term refers to the surgical connection of blood vessels, which is not typically a mechanism involved in the natural healing of skin grafts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imbibition: This occurs primarily in the first two days post-grafting, where the graft absorbs nutrients by diffusion but not through vascular connections.

 

Option C. Neovascularisation: This process begins after the fifth day, contributing to the long-term survival of the graft through the growth of new blood vessels.

 

Option D. Vascular anastomosis: This is not a natural stage of graft healing but refers to the surgical joining of vessels, which is unrelated to the described natural healing stages of grafts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On day 3, a skin graft receives nutrition primarily through inosculation, where early vascular connections form between the graft and the recipient bed, allowing for initial blood supply to the graft.

questions.text: A patient with a history of smoking presents with a cough and hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is done and it is shown below. Which of the following findings is least likely to be associated with this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Exophthalmos

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray findings suggest a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor), which can invade adjacent structures, causing:

 

  • Brachial plexopathy (compression of lower brachial plexus)
  • Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) due to sympathetic chain involvement
  • Superior vena cava syndrome due to compression of the superior vena cava

 

Exophthalmos is more commonly associated with Graves’ disease and is not a feature of Pancoast tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner syndrome: Incorrect because this is a common finding in Pancoast tumor due to involvement of the sympathetic chain

 

Option B. Brachial plexopathy: Incorrect because this is commonly seen due to compression of the lower part of the brachial plexus by the tumor

 

Option C. Superior vena cava syndrome: Incorrect because SVC syndrome can occur in Pancoast tumors due to compression or invasion of the superior vena cava

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors present with Horner’s syndrome, brachial plexopathy, and superior vena cava syndrome, but exophthalmos is not part of the presentation.

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, leading to pain and stiffness. The hallmark feature of AS is inflammatory back pain, which is characterized by pain and stiffness that are worse in the morning and improve with exercise. The persistent red eyes are indicative of anterior uveitis, a common extra-articular manifestation of AS.

 

The reduced lung expansion (less than 3 cm) points towards involvement of the thoracic spine, leading to restrictive lung disease due to reduced chest wall mobility. The X-ray image shows characteristic changes of AS, including syndesmophytes and the "bamboo spine" appearance, which result from the ossification of ligaments and entheses (where tendons and ligaments attach to the bone).

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget's disease: This condition is characterized by abnormal bone remodeling but does not typically present with inflammatory back pain or extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis.
