Option C. Healed tuberculosis: While tuberculosis can affect the spine (Pott's disease), it does not present with the classic inflammatory back pain or the characteristic radiographic changes seen in AS.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: This is a rare genetic disorder that leads to increased bone density and brittleness but does not present with the clinical and radiographic features of AS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankylosing spondylitis should be suspected in young patients with inflammatory back pain that improves with exercise, reduced lung expansion, and extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis. The "bamboo spine" on X-ray is a characteristic finding in advanced cases of AS.

choices.text: Vitamin B12 deficiency
Folate deficiency
Pyridoxine deficiency

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the classic causes of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Pernicious anemia is a type of megaloblastic anemia caused by autoimmune gastritis and an inability to produce intrinsic factors, resulting in vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Histologically, there is chronic atrophic gastritis with parietal cell loss, a prominent infiltrate of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells similar to those seen in erythroid precursors.

 

There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

 

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the a and B subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Folate deficiency: Folate deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia with macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils but is not typically associated with atrophic gastritis.

 

  • Folate deficiency does not usually present with the same gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting) or the autoimmune component seen in pernicious anemia.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine deficiency: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is associated with sideroblastic anemia, not megaloblastic anemia.

 

  • It does not cause macrocytic anemia or atrophic gastritis.

 

Option D. Niacin deficiency: Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the "4 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death.

 

  • It does not cause macrocytic anemia or atrophic gastritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency, often due to pernicious anemia, is characterized by macrocytic anemia, hypersegmented neutrophils, and atrophic gastritis. This condition involves an autoimmune mechanism that impairs the production and function of intrinsic factor, essential for vitamin B12 absorption.

questions.text: Sludder’s neuralgia is due to compression of anterior ethmoidal nerve by septal spur in the region of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle turbinate

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, also known as anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, occurs due to the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve. This nerve provides sensory innervation to parts of the nasal cavity and the anterior part of the cranial cavity. A septal spur, which is a sharp bony projection from the nasal septum, can impinge on the middle turbinate where the anterior ethmoidal nerve traverses. This compression can cause pain and headache in the regions supplied by the nerve, commonly leading to facial pain and nasal discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior turbinate: While the superior turbinate is located higher in the nasal cavity, it is not typically involved in the compression causing Sludder’s neuralgia. The anterior ethmoidal nerve runs closer to the middle turbinate.

 

Option B. Inferior turbinate: The inferior turbinate is situated lower in the nasal cavity and does not typically come into contact with the septal spur affecting the anterior ethmoidal nerve. Therefore, it is not involved in Sludder’s neuralgia.

 

Option D. Supreme turbinate: The supreme turbinate is an anatomical variant that some individuals have above the superior turbinate. This is not commonly implicated in conditions involving the anterior ethmoidal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, or anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, is caused by the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve by a septal spur in the region of the middle turbinate. This condition results in facial pain and headache due to nerve irritation.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented with chest pain. In an angiogram, her left circumflex artery was found to be stenosed, and a stent was inserted. Her current medications include ASA 75mg OD, atenolol 50mg BID, lovastatin, and lisinopril. What should be done in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Add P2Y12 receptor inhibitor

 

After stent placement, it is crucial to prevent stent thrombosis, which can be life-threatening. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is the standard of care in this scenario. DAPT includes aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor). These medications work synergistically to inhibit platelet aggregation and prevent thrombus formation within the stent.

 

The patient is already on aspirin 75 mg daily, so the addition of a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor is necessary to complete the DAPT regimen. This combination has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of stent thrombosis and other cardiovascular events after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement.

 

Guidelines on the duration of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) –

 

  • Drug-Eluting Stents (DES): A minimum of 6 months of DAPT is recommended. This therapy usually involves the use of aspirin combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) to prevent clot formation around the new stent.
  • Bare Metal Stents (BMS): At least 1 month of DAPT is required. Although the duration is shorter than that for DES, it's crucial for preventing early stent thrombosis.
  • Stents Inserted for Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): If a stent is inserted as part of treatment for ACS, the recommended minimum duration of DAPT extends to 12 months. This extended period helps manage the higher risk of thrombosis and other complications associated with ACS.
  • Current Patient Situation: Ongoing Medication: The patient is already on aspirin. A P2Y12 receptor inhibitor needs to be added to the regimen to complete the DAPT, ensuring optimal protection against clotting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase Aspirin dose: Increasing the aspirin dose does not provide additional benefit in preventing stent thrombosis and is not recommended as part of DAPT. The current dose of 75 mg is adequate when combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor.

 

Option B. Increase atenolol dose: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is used for managing hypertension and angina but does not prevent stent thrombosis. Increasing its dose does not address the immediate need for antiplatelet therapy post-stent placement.

 

Option C. Add a Long-Acting Nitrate: Long-acting nitrates can help manage angina symptoms but do not prevent stent thrombosis. They are not part of the recommended therapy to prevent thrombotic complications after stent placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After stent placement, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor) is essential to prevent stent thrombosis and ensure optimal patient outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has activity against both HBV and HIV? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tenofovir

 

Tenofovir is an antiretroviral medication that is effective against both HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) and HBV (Hepatitis B Virus). It is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that works by inhibiting the action of reverse transcriptase, an enzyme crucial for the replication of both HIV and HBV. Tenofovir is commonly used in the treatment of HIV infection and is also a key component in the management of chronic hepatitis B, particularly in patients co-infected with HIV and HBV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abacavir: This is another NRTI used in the treatment of HIV but it does not have significant activity against HBV.

 

Option C. Nevirapine: A non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used in the treatment of HIV, with no activity against HBV.

 

Option D. Enfuvirtide: A fusion inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV that works by preventing the virus from entering the cells. It does not have activity against HBV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs effective against both HIV and HBV coinfection: Lamivudine, Emtricitabine and Tenofovir

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for managing the school health programs? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Primary health center

 

  • In India, the School Health Committee recommended that school health services be integrated with general health services, which are managed by primary health centers (PHCs).
  • To ensure effective implementation, the committee proposed the formation of school health committees at various levels. PHCs are responsible for providing a range of school health services such as health assessments, vision and hearing tests, dental check-ups, treatment for common illnesses, immunization, micronutrient management, deworming, and provision of mid-day meals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are responsible for managing school health programs in India, providing a range of health services to ensure the well-being of school children.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pharyngobasilar Fascia

 

The arrow in the image points to the pharyngobasilar fascia, which is a key fascia in the tonsillar region. The pharyngobasilar fascia is a modification of the deep cervical fascia that extends between the skull base and the pharyngeal muscles. It helps form the bed of the tonsil along with other structures and provides structural support to the pharynx. In the tonsillar region, the pharyngobasilar fascia forms part of the complex fascial arrangements that include the capsule, loose areolar tissue, and other fascial layers.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Superior Constrictor: Incorrect because the superior constrictor muscle lies deep to the marked structure and is a muscular component rather than a fascial layer.

 

Option B. Capsule: Incorrect because the tonsillar capsule is a distinct structure that immediately surrounds the tonsillar tissue, whereas the marked structure is a broader fascial layer.

 

Option C. Buccopharyngeal Fascia: Incorrect because the buccopharyngeal fascia is another fascial modification that lies external to the pharyngobasilar fascia and covers the buccinator muscle and pharyngeal muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fig: Relations of tonsil. Tonsil is related laterally to its capsule (1), loose areolar tissue containing paraton- sillar vein (2), superior constrictor muscle (3), styloglossus (4), glossopharyngeal nerve (5), facial artery (6), medial pterygoid muscle (7), angle of mandible (8) and sub- mandibular salivary gland (9), pharyngobasilar fascia (10), buccopharyngeal fascia (11).

questions.text: In a given population, total births were 4050 including 50 stillbirths in a given year. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life, and an additional 150 die within 8-28 days of life. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in the population? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50

 

The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is a key indicator of neonatal health and is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births. The neonatal period spans from birth up to 28 days and is further divided into:

 

  • Early Neonatal Period: 0-7 days
  • Late Neonatal Period: 8-28 days

 

Calculation:

 

  • Total births: 4050 (including 50 stillbirths)
  • Neonatal deaths:
    • Early Neonatal Period: 50 deaths
    • Late Neonatal Period: 150 deaths
  • Total Neonatal Deaths: 50 + 150 = 200 deaths
  • Total Live Births: 4050 - 50 (stillbirths) = 4000 live births
  • Neonatal Mortality Rate Formula:

 

 

  • Calculate NMR

 

 

Thus, the Ans.  is 50 per 1000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births.
